It's a fun, simple, and fast-paced mobile version of the sweet Xbox Civ Rev 2 game. HOWEVER, the AI sometimes is non-existent/dumb, city conversions & lost battles happen with no warning, the computer forgets to execute unit actions during larger games, and matches end at 2100 AD, right when technology starts to get good. There is also limbo "coming soon" content. Game needs bug/glitch fixes, longer matches, tweaks, and finished content... but is playable (mostly). Needs more work & a dev team.

Will keep you occupied for a few hours. Maps are very small (smaller than I remember from the xbox version) so you'll find other civilisations more or less right next to you when you start, which means theres not a massive amount of the map to explore and discover the other civilisations which I miss from the other civ games. I would recommend trying the harder difficulties for a decent challenge. Really needs an update after 5 years. Worth picking up on sale.

Been playing it for years now. No ads, medium difficulty and easy once mastered. It's a great way to kill time. I give 4 stars because it has crashed occasionally on my S7 while not on game mode but it saves well. I've never lost awards. Sure it could have more stats and be more complex, but I never find this game annoying.
Battle results should not change based on difficulty level. A 5 strength should always beat a 2.

I love civilization and this is an ok version of it. It can never compare to the occasional version but this game is definitely ok for a cellphone game. However it should be a free game or at least cheaper.
This is nowhere close to civ computer. Sadly i expected much more. I wish i still had the refund option. 😒

Similar to the PC version but with much-much simpler gameplay and GUI. Simpler also means faster gameplay but it does good on a mobile platform. Sometimes it reminds me of the original Civ from 1992 but in a good (nostalgic) way. A few elements are a bit unbalanced (for example some wonders and artifacts provide insanely big advantages) and I could use a bit more statistics or a better city review panel, but all-in-all I really enjoy playing this game! I had no compatibility issues on Android 9.

It worked fine for me with my HTC U11 and now a message saying "looking for resources to download" pops up in my notifications and the app just crashes each time I try to load it. I guess we're all just supposed to just accept that EA cares more about the money than user experience and continue to ignore all the user complaints on Google Play. I guess they already have the money, so no need to make something actually work after the fact.
Great game abandoned by the devs. Would love a hot seat multiplayer or asynchronous multiplayer as seen on Civ 6, but the gameplay itself is solid and a decent expansion upon the first Civ Rev.
Used to love this game now when i click on a spot it chooses the next block. Game sucks now. Would play again if this was fixed

Played for about an hour and realized how small the world was. Disappointed. I was seriously excited for this. I wish I could get a refund cause I'll never play it again after realizing the tiny map size. I want to get engrossed for days or weeks in one game like in the old days. Definitely have to boot up my PC now.
love it

Bad experience! Does not save progress. You play all day long and you go so far and then you press Save button and go to sleep. Next day you want to continue the progress but! When you load the game it kicks you back to the "Almost the begining!" Like a few turns after you started. Very disappointing experience. You can not save the game and take some rest. You have to play it on a single breath from start to finish otherwise you shall lose your progress.
Amazing it runs so well. Gets a bit glitchy on bigger/longer games and my achievements have stopped so I can't unlock anymore leaders annoyingly.

Edit #5000! So the CPU sometimes builds new units every turn even when it's too early for that to be possible. Units get deleted or downgraded from armies to singles between saves. Just now, Egypt built two wonders that I had already built (Scotland Yard, Eiffel Tower) and they were not present in the city where I had them. I'm just trying to get the achievements. Oh, and I once had a ton of those and then I didn't anymore. This game isn't worthy of the Civilization title.

Very disappointing. EA has not updated this games compatibility with newer phones. In fact, they haven't added an update since ----> 2014!!!! Not to mention the fact that it is missing key features from the original game. Even when it was operational, it was usually impossible to finish a game without crashing and losing all progress after endless hours.

The game runs smoothly without any errors, so there is a star for that. I do not like games/apps that force you to spend hours looking up videos or other outside information on how to play the game. Not win, but play. Which is exactly what this game requires. Anyone can mindlessly build things, but you have no idea what does what. Maybe other people could enjoy the "challenge", but I found it to be a complete waste of time.
It's almost a good game, thus the 3*. If you want a game to play before getting into a proper civ game try this. If you already play civ don't waste your money.

The most frustrating version of Civ I have ever played. The AI armies are nearly invincible. You will watch as rifleman units shoot down your bombers and a pikeman holds off your Tanks. It is unbelievably aggravating. It seems the only advantage the AI has is these overpowered units. It certainly is not capable of any sort of advanced strategy. Put your phone in a tough case because you will be tempted to throw it.

Плюсы: это Цивилизация, пошаговая 4Х-стратегия. Хороший перевод на русский язык. Минусы: лишние разрешения - "Contacts" ("find accounts on the device") и "Wi-Fi connection information" ("view Wi-Fi connections"). плохая оптимизация для больших экранов. Слишком малые карты. На экране дипломатии нет цветов и собственно нации собеседника, состояние отношения с этим государством. Нет сводных данных о своей цивилизации. На экране города нет сведений о расквартированных войсках. После победы нельзя продолжить играть. При всей любви к десктопным играм сериала смог заставить себя пройти лишь дважды.

The worst game by Sid Meyer ever. They took Civ 1, added 3D graphics and removed most of functionality. No city management, no terrain upgrades, dubious diplomacy... you won't be able even to abandon a unit (so once you build a lesson, you'll live with it even in the future era, unless you lose it in a battle)

Civilization games by Sid Meyers simply best. I've played many incarnations over years. If what you want is purely militaty conquest, non-stop combat and buying off difficulty look elsewhere. If a game containing other paths that add to success such as diplomacy ,tech, culture and economy,here it is. If you've won several military victories, challenge yourself with a cultural or economic world victory. Close enough to P.C.CIV to get 5 starts from me.

A rare occurrence where the sequel is far and away a worse game than the original. No customizability whatsoever (not even a settings menu to speak of!), tiny maps, slow animations (no "fast forward" mode like the original), terrible UI design and coding, and less depth than the original civ rev. Very disappointing, given the $6.50 pricetag. This feels more like a demo than a full game.

Ethnocentric eugenics made easy. Unabashedly uses racial termanology. Tribal people can't win and always die. Religions are mocked openly. Anyone can win the hardest mode so the leaderboards and achievements are broken, same bugs as Civ 5 all still here. There is nothing that stands up to Stellaris, or Endless Legend, especially on the phone.

This is a fun game. Positive. Scenarios, even a scenario generator, 5 different difficulty settings, lots of troops and lots of fun learning which is 'your type' of troops. Sadly there is a lot of negative as well. Bugs include {not exhaustive} 1) Cannot enter into conquered cities 2) No upd. in soon 5 years 3) Randomly change turn 4) Really stupid AI (Attacks when it really should not, declares war at silly rates, no way to really nego. Sad stuff. Remove Sid Meyer from the label!

Fan of the Civilization PC games? Here's a weaker version. It's still fun, but dont expect the full experience. Ultimately there's a lot of fun to be had in this game, and it accommodates multiple play styles, and all of this without being overly complicated.

This is a beta game that the developers never bothered to fix. There are tons of bugs, the gameplay is repetitive after a few play-throughs, and the mechanisms in the game are opaque (e.g. you are told only that a building "increases" output of something). The game is also likely used to steal information about users, as it asks for offline access (the ability to get your information from Google even when you are not using the game) and the ability to read, modify, and delete your calendars.

Civ Rev for console is my favorite console game ever. I put this on my tablet for when I am not able to play on my console. It stinks. The problem with this version is that the AI cheats. It doesn't let you finish your turns after a save. Where normally you must "end turn" to signify you have ended your turn, if you have saved the game and load it later, after some reflection on strategy, it will automatically end your turn immediately without your consent. Thus, if you have things to do- troops to reinforce, production to change you are out of luck. I have lost a shocking number of cities this way. It is super irritatating. But this is even worse. Apparently, the AI doesn't have to abide by the same rules of the game as players. If one of the civilizations I"m playing against has a democracy, they glean the scientific and economic benefits of a democracy. However, in this version of the game, they do not have to accept the cost of a democracy, which is to cease war if offered peace. They simply refuse to engage in talks. As a player, you must pay this cost, so it makes your odds of winning where the rules are uneven based more on chaos theory than actual strategy. The two stars were for the expanded leaders and the expanded techs, which were nice but not critical to game play, unlike unfortunately, the flaws with this version. I played every civilization and won in every way on console but honestly don't think I'll pick up this poorly designed version of the game again. There are better games on the play store.

I have spent tons of time on this game. I like it for the most part. I like how the different civilizations affect gameplay and that you have to play to their strengths. You can use terrain to win battles that you might have lost. There's naval battles, fights for air superiority and fighting over choke points and resources. Plus they leave options for using culture to beat a militarily stronger opponent. What I dislike is the lack of diplomacy. It's always "give us this technology or die" and then it a strength check. Also, it seems like there is a flaw in the combat system. I don't think I've ever heard of a fighter jet being shot down by a musket, but it happens alot here. Also, the units are usually represented in 3s but some of the stronger units only have 2, so sometimes the 3s beat the 2s or 1s just because it had 3 troops representing the unit. It leads to some frustration. Then there's a huge skill gap in the Warlord and King difficulty. It feels like you'll play regular and suddenly all enemies have Infantrymen attacking your Archers because they somehow managed to all discover gunpowder in 3 turns (exaggeration). All in all, I enjoy the game, just wish there was a little more depth to the diplomacy with other nations and the combat mechanics were tweaked.

Civilization Revolution 2 Is Ok Game. But if you came here expecting Mobile version of PC Civ you will be surely disappointed. This game dumps all of the core game mechanics straight in to the dumpster. There is no city states, no customisable world size, and maybe the worst thing may be that you can't build stuff since there is no workers. There is limited amount of turns. But if you came here as new to the whole Francaise or just to be able to play casual Civ here and there on mobile you came to right-ish place. The game is fun overall but it is a complete mockery of what Civilization Is Today. I Honestly can,t suggest this to any one expect those casual players. And the price of the game is totally unjustifiably high. Summary Do Not Buy This Game If You Expected Something Like PC Civilization. This game will otherwise leave you disappointed and annoyed

Civ Rev is a good game but this version is broken in the following regards.  The AI never attacks barbarians. This leads to them never expanding and makes every game trivial. The AI only moves units one space per turn, even on roads. The difficulty levels are all too easy. Random enemy units spawn by your cities and attack them in the same turn. (Normal in other Civ Rev games too)  Once you give an order to move a unit several spaces it can't be cancelled.  Attacking or moving a unit upwards is frustrating due to the tooltip style unit infobox blocking the tile.  No multiplayer.  No management options (governors) for when you have many cities.

I really want to like this game. I've been playing the Civ series and its spinoffs for nearly 20 years. My gripe is with the inability to access the city screen - it just disappears, taking the ability to manage the build queue and your ability to wage war with it. Sometimes it comes back for a turn or two but then goes away again. Looking back in the reviews shows this glitch is several years old and the developer still hasn't fixed the issue despite releasing subsequent updates. This is disappointing on a few levels - this app costs money and it has Sid Meiers' name on it, both of which entitle a consumer to believe an app won't be so consumed with bugs that it precludes essential functions.

I love the original versions of this game. I'd enjoy this one too if it didn't keep freezing my phone. I have a Samsung Galaxy S7 with plenty of memory, so there's no reason for the game to crash. Good but could be better -  good stuff first: reminds me of the classic civil games, the game play is there and I've spent many hours on it. Strategy is important - you can only win the game if you have a good one Unlockable world leaders - beat the game on king difficulty to meet the challenges and you unlock leaders with different attributes  Bad stuff -  Controls - frustrating to move units, especially when a city name gets in the way, or you select another unit when trying to move another. Also, you can't put a unit to 'sleep' - for example, build a nuclear missile and you have to tell it to wait every single turn, often more than once per turn   Winning - if you achieve a victory, the game won't let you keep playing beyond that. So you can't get an economic victory and then stay on and wipe out everyone. You also can't play beyond 2100, which is a shame   In all pretty decent, but some tweaks and TLC could make it 5*

Having played Civ Rev 1 on the Nintendo DS for many hours I was very keen to get Civ Rev 2 to experience more of the same goodness.   But this isn't the game I envisioned it would be. The core gameplay is intact with minor differences, but the AI is seriously impaired. That alone kills almost all enjoyment. Other problems include the controls which are very tedious to cycle through and bugs which prevent you from receiving rewards for reaching new tech first or milestones first.  But the biggest letdown is the AI.  In CivRev 1 the AI would attack barbarians and each other, in CivRev2 the AI civs don't attack barbarians and for some reason never ever come into contact with other civs.   This just results in every AI player just attacking you, no diplomacy between AI civs at all kills so much of your diplomatic options which defeats being a 4X game.  The game hasn't seen an update in a long time and I doubt any will come out soon, if you want 4X on android, this one barely scratches it.  I'd give this 2 and a half stars if i could, but since i can't, it'll be 3 stars. Be aware that I find gameplay to be a step back from CivRev 1, and unlike the first, I'm hardly ever playing this one. Its gotten far fewer hours of my attention than the first.

I've run circles around the AI players on all of those, and still the menu disappears and never comes back.  The game is unplayable without the ability to build anything.

I won the game numerous times with nothing more than Roman Legions and Galleys in the Industrial Age between 400BC and 200AD. This game is an adaptation of the main games on PC for mobile and the second game on mobile. There are some rule changes from the PC games such as one can settle cities close together and science and gold production are linked, thus one cannot build wealth or gold at the same time. Surprisingly, these rules streamline the game while still keeping the difficulty of the PC games which I like. However, my biggest gripe is with the bugs. Many of the bugs interrupt gameplay and requires a restart to fix.

I can live with that, but not with the uneven combat (on warlord difficulty, your tanks will be defeated by fortified archers), and the 100% reproducible bug where if I switch to a different app, when I return, the city screen no longer functions and I have to restart.
A good adaptation for a mobile platform. Easy to pick up, fun to follow up on. Not as complicated as its PC big brother, so easy for playing on the go.

This game is awesome, and I say that as someone who has played Civilization games since Civ 1.  The game is a bit simplified, but this is necessary for a game that will probably be played in small doses rather than in marathon sessions.  When you come back, your advisers will all tell you how close you are to the various victory conditions making it easy to pick up where you left off.  The relatively small maps with smaller number of opponents on them also make games shorter and easier to pick back up.  Overall, this game was well-designed, and it's got that great "just..one...more...turn" aspect that is the hallmark of the Civilization series.  It also runs perfectly on my Moto G 3rd Gen; I had none of the freezing, crashing or other problems others have mentioned.  It didn't heat my phone up and it never became unresponsive.  I also love the fact that I paid for it once and got the whole game.

Pro's  - fun simplified version of the PC game.  Its fairly easy to pick up the game play.  Biggest pro is I think it's one of the few strategy game on mobile platform that isn't "Pay to Win".  Cons' - simplified is an understatement. It's missing many of the key features and game play aspects that make the PC version a great game. It's pretty expensive for what you get. (Typical of big game designers)  It's got quite a few bugs and no update support.  It also is a huge battery hog... I can only play for about an hour unless I'm plugged in.

So, I'd wasted a lot of time on the original version on iPhone and thought this might be an improvement, as that one, despite its addicting nature, was buggy as hell: 1) Why the F*** does a game need access to my calendars?! No, no, and no! 2) Still buggy, town dialogs disappear and a game restart is required to get them back. 3) Interface is prettier, but the basic problem of features obscuring other features (hard to move units north, or to see units to the north of a town under the label) Same AI engine, i.e. stupid. So basically, I blew 10 bucks to get a new version of the same game.

Updated from previous 4 star review... I liked this game,  but it's not actively developed or supported anymore. Love this game. Worth the 💰. Great update and improvement over the first CivRev Mobile. Great graphics, multiple leaders per country, and unique units for each nation are terrific upgrades from last title. With tons of achievements and unlockables, and with constantly updated scenarios, it keeps the replay value high. My second favorite mobile game behind Star Wars: KotOR. 5/5 🌟 easy

It's a very nice game, and the unlockable characters helps you adopt different play styles. However, it's very similar (almost identical) to the first revolution game, and it's lacking the "one more turn" feature from the pc games. You just don't have enough control on the length of the game, and you don't get to see the aftermath of your victory. It really makes victory a goal you don't want to reach because you want to play longer! It is also lacking multiplayer, and playing with AI gets dull over time.

I loved civ Rev on the 360 and civ Rev 2 was my 1st Google play purchase. It is basically the same as the 1st one with a few more goodies thrown in (new wonders, technology, leaders, military). Don't listen to the whining retards who own crap phones/tablets as I've experienced NONE of the problems their moaning about. If your IQ is larger than your shoe size than you will figure out the controls easily. This can be played offline, and no in app purchases or pop up ads. It has never crashed once on me, and ive played a quite a few games in the few months ive owned this. You can save and load your games, and it does not eat up battery life like some ppl are crying about. For instance, during a power outage today, my Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 8.0 was at 90% power. After playing nearly two hours, I was around 50%. I consider this my best purchase off of the store so far and would purchase it again in a heartbeat. P.s. Aztecs for the win!
This game will have me playing for hours at a time. You get so wrapped up into building your civ you just get lost. Worth the purchase

content: I absolutely love playing civilization. I own it for the pc, console and even have the original Civ:: Rev. Despite the price tag I turned to this game after getting fed up with pretty much every 'free to play' strategy game on the mobile market. When I'm waiting at a train station I don't want a three day real-time wait for a basic building or item of research. Civilization Revolution 2 has a wealth of challenges and game modes. There are no in-app purchases, you get the whole game straight away without cash-grab impedance. It's good fun once you realise it's a super cut-down and streamlined rendition of Civ.
I can play this game for hours and hours!

If you are a fan of the original Civilization Revolution you will love it. It's almost identical to Civ Rev, but with an updated user interface and polished graphics. Save often because the game does crash. I lost hours of gameplay troubleshooting various crashes and I almost lost it. However, I am determined to get this game to work on my tablet! I was able to avoid the offline app approval crash by going to the Play Store, then settings menu, then turn off authentication for purchase. If you don't disable this, your game will eventually crash and lose all unsaved gameplay. Make sure you don't turn screen rotation off/on during gameplay to avoid a possible crash. If you have power save/screen dim activated your game might crash upon waking up from screen dim. Very fun, but it needs an update.

I'm a big fan of the civ games so I would love to see some adjustments made then I will re-rate. I'm playing on a tab 4 and the game play is pretty solid. Sometimes it's a bit much to handle and it gets jumpy, but that's to be expected. I have two minor problems with this. Special forces? Their junk. Idk if your trying to make it more like the comp games where archers and such are used as offensive units? If that's the case here's your problem. Unlike civ5 these cities don't have standalone defenses. So 1. either leave both special forces and infantry as choices, or 2. raise special forces defense some. And the other issue I have is the troop movement. I like the idea of the bar at the bottom to shuffle through your troops but it gets absolutely annoying when your trying to unload a ship or troop transport and every time you get one unit off  it jumps to an idle unit all the way across the map. Actually now I have brought up an issue I had forgotten,  the ships. I think you should implement the ability to unload troops from ships like in civ rev 1. Make it a button opposite the defense button.

If you're looking for a mobile version of Civilization V, Civilization Revolution 2 isn't where you should be spending money. Here's a litany of issues/annoyance that make this game bad:   Troops cannot be (easily) selected or un-fortified, causing sloppy troop movement and an overall frustrating combat situations.  Cities keep pumping out the same units until manually stopped. Troops cannot be sold, causing them to fill up your map if production is left unchecked. Technology tree is an abomination; it doesn't let you select an advance tech to work towards (or select a tech in the tree), nor does it show the relationships between techs at a glance. Tabbing out saves your turn, but makes you reload the entire game. Other countries constantly try to take money from you. Ranged items, such as catapults, aren't actually ranged and can be destroyed in one attack. Feels barebones to the PC version. Doesn't play like a typical Civ game

The beauty of the Civilization line of games is realized when hours of strategic thinking and delayed gratification are suddenly converted into victory.  That beauty is lost here.  The game mechanics are fine, though the storyline has been eliminated.  You pick a scenario with a thin premise and "go."  The civilizations seem more unevenly matched than before, a bit more stereotyped and a lot less fun.  The depth is gone all around.  The game is harder, and you have less room to breathe.    Maybe this is because of the small screen and the strange touch mechanics.  I am playing this on a phablet, and I cannot imagine using a "normal" sized phone (like a Samsung Galaxy S6), or even fathom using "chit"-sized iphone screen.  I am happy that I bought the game, but I won't be playing it for a while.  It's too unrewarding, and it makes me feel a bit hollow.
For $10 I expected a smooth stable experience and not crashing before you even get to finish a turn. I have free games that run smoother than this game. Do not buy this game till they fix it.

I love this game. Do not expect this game to be like civ on pc, because it isn't. It is a very different game and I like it. However, it crashes way too much. It will crash multiple times per game. Luckily it does have an auto save feature, so you don't lose too much progress.  The game is also very stuttery at times. This wouldn't be too bad, but now when I try to load a game that it crashed on, it crashes when trying to load and now I guess I have lost all my progress on it. If this is fixed, 5 stars.

First up, this does play like Civ. No coin collecting or farmville, though the world is more condensed, so you meet barbarians faster (killing them rewards with gold).   It's fun, it runs well on Shield, the games can be fairly long, it looks pretty, there is lots of variety (the full tech tree is there, and has similar effects).  Simple negatives (why not 5 stars): - No hotseat multiplayer - Winning ends the game instantly - The AI has a tendency to just... roll over and die. (your tanks vs their warriors) - The game asks permission to manage my Google calendars on boot. Never happening! - The game is complex, without much guidance! e.g. armies are made by stacking 3, civopedia is stowed in a menu, and you can micromanage city production.  Finally, let's compare to Civ 5. That it even bears comparing should say something. Civ 5 is like a pinnacle of strategy gaming - and this is a different range of hills, but also a high point (and certainly a pinnacle on native android). Civ revolution plays more like Civ 4 (e.g. stacking units). Everything is smaller (maps, cities, etc).   All in all: Very enjoyable!
Awesome

The gameplay is what I expected and loved: a toned-down Civilizations game adapted for quicker play on the move. That part's great.  However, I'm disappointed by the over-production: playing on a HTC One M7 (2013), it lags every time it plays an animation. I don't care about the animation: sure they're fun the first few times, but after the 10th, you just have to endure them, let alone the 30th. Really, the 3D graphics get in the way of the gameplay.  The controls can be a bit cramped, beware a mis-touch in a diplomatic interaction! Otherwise, I accept the constraints of playing this on a phone.  I wish there was a 2D version of the game, which would provide the excellent just-one-more-turn gameplay with smooth graphics.

Like almost all Civilization editions, this game is highly addictive. It has nice graphics and animations and it works well on my Nexus 5. There are a few flaws though (writing them down in case developers look at this review): - 'Allow Offline Access' is not sticky and appears every 10-20 minutes. There's an associated bug where the screen goes black and the game crashes occasionally when this happens. Luckily there are autosaves every round. - The game has an enormous battery drain, to the point where my phone discharges slowly even when the charging cable is plugged in. - For normal games (starting BC) I don't see the point in all those late technologies and city improvements -- the game is pretty much decided. - Trying to move a unit up one tile into a city doesn't work well, I always activate a different unit in the target tile instead. - Loading is too slow for my taste. Saving is quick. - If you are a bit ahead in technology the game becomes easy around renaissance time because you get lots of goodies for discovering things first. I find that a bit too generous. - Units have only a fortify but not a sleep mode. That can result in the enemy approaching without notice.

I'm an avid Civ fan and obsessive Civ Rev player and was excited to get this game but it's an AWFUL port. The touch interface is nothing but frustrating. With no way to skip a unit's turn, or stop a unit's route once set (accidentally or not), and only the most convoluted way to switch between units, the game becomes unplayable.   Interface aside the game is okay but little more than a clone of Civ Rev on consoles. It crashes pretty frequently on my 2013 Nexus 7 which adds insult to injury ($14.99!). Nothing new here, unworkable interface, and even smaller world maps than Civ Rev. I am deeply disappointed as I was thrilled that this finally came to the android platform.

Graphics: 9/10. Audio 9/10. Concept: 10/10. Execution: 1/10. This game has so much potential but the gameplay is shallow. There's no strategy because the paths to advance and to victory are laid out. Also, like all civ games, the AI is dumb as rocks. Do not recommend.

Whoever is responsible for the terrible lack of play testing/low replayability should hang their head in shame.  Not worth the premium price.

This is just what I wanted! A civilization experience on my tablet. It's a little less complicated then the PC versions, but this is still a Civilization game. But other then that this game is great! I also can't tell you how happy I am to see a paid game without microtransactions. I also want to say I've never experienced a crash yet, and I've been playing it multiple times a day, several matches played to completion. I'm happy that 2K release this game with Premium model, no microtransaction nor any other IAP to cash-in more money from paying customer. Kudos for you 2K.  Now to review the game itself. My main issue is that i can't play this game online as it always tries to login to 2K server but fail miserably; making the game impossible. What can be done is to turn off your wifi/data plan before opening the game. I will give 5 stars when 2K fix this error.  Now the game itself is wonderful, the graphics are great and stories are, well, Civilization like (seriously no story needed for this game). Love it. The game ran smoothly on my Galaxy Note 8.0 with very little frame drop. I haven't played multiplayer due to game cannot connect to server. Will give more review when this issue is fixed.  Now, 2K, please give us Bioshock.
Great game could you a little more work.  One i really noticed that was really annoying is that you can't tell apart the Warriors and army. Once you join them
Runs amazing on the S5. No issues, whatsoever. Runs smooth and very fast!

i had problems with the signing in thing like everyone else.. to solve it turn your screen rotation on and hold the screen side ways. it'll allow the login window to popup to load in landscape because the code doesnt force it to which is what is hiding the login screen
Just like everyone else... game screws up at sign in,  and I couldn't go further. I had to  turn auto rotate on,  and now it works.  so far,  so good!

Long time Civ player, first time playing Revolution... Not really my cup of tea, don't get me wrong, it's a very polished well made game, it just doesn't have that epic grand scale feeling that you are building a mighty empire thru the passage of time, like a regular Civ game. Revolutions just seems to progress way too fast. I ran into my rivals in no time, & some how got into the industrial age in a blink of an eye! This is more of a casual war game made for quick bursts of play, which is ok for a mobile. I would like to see a full Civ game on android someday, but I will take this in the mean time. Maybe this will interest new players to look into the rest of the Civ franchise, & the 4x genre in general. I would like to thank 2k for making a full game with no strings.. I gladly paid the whole sticker price upfront.

The game is dumbed down to the point that it only slightly better than most other Android titles, making it not really worth the $15 price tag. Don't expect that just 1 more turn magic. If you don't really care about the cost, it is at least a little better than other Android titles.
This game has awesome potential but unfortunately it doesn't work I'm outraged that I spent a tenner on it

I would like to think that a large studio could make a more stable app. The fact that it needs to sign in and seems to require a constant connection is ridiculous as well. I loved CIV Rev but this games needs some work.
Nexus 9 tablet gets burning hot and battery drains very fast. I understand this is a video game but when idle (which is most of the time) I would think the game would use less power.
The game crashes all the time. It's unplayable, and that's such a shame, especially for this price where you expect a full game (which you get) and a working game (which you don't).

First review:- The graphics:astonishing 9/10-The sounds:8.5/10-The game play:I will not spoil the game,try it - Is it pricy: of course NO, no in game purchase,thank God,you are free- Need an update?urgently:to smooth the game more,to solve the sign-in problem(skip it by activating airplane mode),to slow the years counter it's fast- In general the rate of the game compared to CIV4 & CIV5 and taking in the consideration that it's on a mobile device and it's not an IAP:8/10 and I will say 8.5-9/10 after update

This is a great translation of Civ to mobile. Just keep two things in mind: 1 - This is not Civilization V. This is more of a "bite sized" Civ, perfect for portable, on the go gaming. Don't expect the full PC Civilization experience. 2 - Many reviews of Civ Rev 2 for iOS made the same statement: This is a great game if you don't already own Civ Rev 1. I completely agree. This is Civ Rev 1 with a fresh coat of paint, and some new leaders/civs. However, Civ Rev 1 was never released for Android, making Civ Rev 2 a little more essential for Android gamers.
